data.main_text:
The Home Run Boom in Baseball ‚Äî Visualized with R
Posted on
October 10, 2025
by
rprogrammingbooks
in
R bloggers
| 0 Comments
[This article was first published on
Blog - R Programming Books
, and kindly contributed to
R-bloggers
].  (You can report issue about the content on this page
here
)
Want to share your content on R-bloggers?
click here
if you have a blog, or
here
if you don't.
From the dead-ball era to the launch-angle revolution
Baseball has always evolved, but few trends tell a clearer story of transformation than the
rise of the home run
.
A century ago, hitting even a handful of home runs in a season was an achievement. Today, it‚Äôs an expectation.
Thanks to better training, analytics, and even changes in ball composition, home runs have skyrocketed ‚Äî literally.
Let‚Äôs explore
how home runs per game have changed in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1901 to today
, and what that means for the modern game (and even for betting markets
).
The Data Story
We‚Äôll use the
Lahman Baseball Database
‚Äî one of the most complete historical baseball datasets ‚Äî to calculate the number of
home runs per game
in each MLB season since 1901.
Here‚Äôs the R code to reproduce the visualization:
‚Äî 1) Packages ‚Äî
packages <- c(‚Äútidyverse‚Äù, ‚ÄúLahman‚Äù, ‚Äúscales‚Äù, ‚Äúgganimate‚Äù, ‚Äúgifski‚Äù)
to_install <- packages[!packages %in% installed.packages()[, ‚ÄúPackage‚Äù]]
if (length(to_install)) install.packages(to_install, dependencies = TRUE)
library(tidyverse)
library(Lahman)
library(scales)
library(gganimate)
library(gifski)
‚Äî 2) Build season-level metrics (HR per game) ‚Äî
Teams table: HR (team home runs), G (team games). Each game involves 2 teams.
season_hr <- Teams %>%
filter(!is.na(HR), !is.na(G), yearID >= 1901) %>%
group_by(yearID) %>%
summarise(
hr_total = sum(HR, na.rm = TRUE),
games_team_total = sum(G, na.rm = TRUE),
.groups = ‚Äúdrop‚Äù
) %>%
mutate(
games_league = games_team_total / 2, # each game counted by two teams
hr_per_game = hr_total / games_league
)
For labels: detect peak and recent year available in Lahman
peak <- season_hr %>% slice_max(hr_per_game, n = 1)
latest_year <- max(season_hr$yearID, na.rm = TRUE)
‚Äî 3) Static plot ‚Äî
p_static <- ggplot(season_hr, aes(yearID, hr_per_game)) +
geom_line(linewidth = 1) +
geom_smooth(se = FALSE, method = ‚Äúloess‚Äù, span = 0.2) +
geom_point(data = peak, aes(yearID, hr_per_game), size = 3) +
ggrepel::geom_text_repel(
data = peak,
aes(label = paste0(‚ÄúPeak: ‚Äú, yearID, ‚Äú\n‚Äù, round(hr_per_game, 2), ‚Äù HR/game‚Äù)),
nudge_y = 0.1, min.segment.length = 0
) +
scale_x_continuous(breaks = pretty_breaks()) +
scale_y_continuous(labels = label_number(accuracy = 0.01)) +
labs(
title = ‚ÄúThe Home Run Boom in MLB‚Äù,
subtitle = paste0(‚ÄúLeague-wide home runs per game, 1901‚Äì‚Äù, latest_year),
x = ‚ÄúSeason‚Äù,
y = ‚ÄúHome runs per game (league-wide)‚Äù,
caption = ‚ÄúSource: Lahman Baseball Database | Made in R‚Äù
) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
theme(
plot.title = element_text(face = ‚Äúbold‚Äù),
plot.caption = element_text(margin = margin(t = 8))
)
Save static image
ggsave(‚Äúmlb_hr_per_game.png‚Äù, p_static, width = 10, height = 6.2, dpi = 220)
‚Äî 4) Optional: by league (AL vs NL) small multiples ‚Äî
season_hr_lg <- Teams %>%
filter(!is.na(HR), !is.na(G), yearID >= 1901, !is.na(lgID)) %>%
group_by(yearID, lgID) %>%
summarise(
hr_total = sum(HR, na.rm = TRUE),
games_team_total = sum(G, na.rm = TRUE),
.groups = ‚Äúdrop_last‚Äù
) %>%
mutate(games_league = games_team_total / 2,
hr_per_game = hr_total / games_league) %>%
ungroup()
p_facets <- ggplot(season_hr_lg, aes(yearID, hr_per_game)) +
geom_line() +
geom_smooth(se = FALSE, method = ‚Äúloess‚Äù, span = 0.25) +
facet_wrap(~ lgID, nrow = 2) +
labs(
title = ‚ÄúAL vs NL: home runs per game over time‚Äù,
subtitle = paste0(‚Äú1901‚Äì‚Äù, latest_year),
x = ‚ÄúSeason‚Äù,
y = ‚ÄúHR per game‚Äù,
caption = ‚ÄúSource: Lahman Baseball Database | Made in R‚Äù
) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +
theme(plot.title = element_text(face = ‚Äúbold‚Äù))
ggsave(‚Äúmlb_hr_per_game_al_vs_nl.png‚Äù, p_facets, width = 10, height = 7, dpi = 220)
‚Äî 5) Optional animated line (season build-up) ‚Äî
p_anim <- ggplot(season_hr, aes(yearID, hr_per_game)) +
geom_line() +
geom_point(size = 1.5) +
labs(
title = ‚ÄúMLB Home Runs per Game ‚Äî {closest_state}‚Äù,
subtitle = paste0(‚Äú1901‚Äì‚Äù, latest_year),
x = ‚ÄúSeason‚Äù,
y = ‚ÄúHR per game‚Äù,
caption = ‚ÄúSource: Lahman Baseball Database | Made in R (gganimate)‚Äù
) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
transition_reveal(yearID)
animate(
p_anim,
width = 900, height = 540,
fps = 30, duration = 12, end_pause = 10,
renderer = gifski_renderer(‚Äúmlb_hr_per_game.gif‚Äù)
)
‚Äî 6) Ready-to-post bullet points (adjust as needed) ‚Äî
‚Äì Home runs per game have trended upward over the long run, with notable surges in recent decades.
‚Äì The peak season in the dataset is flagged on the chart.
‚Äì AL and NL show broadly similar patterns, with era-specific differences.
‚Äì Context matters: ball composition, launch-angle era, and strategic shifts all play a role.
ou‚Äôll get a clean, publication-quality chart like this:
(Insert your generated image
mlb_home_run_trend.png
here)
What the Numbers Tell Us
1900s‚Äì1910s (Dead-ball era):
Home runs were almost mythical. Pitchers dominated, and balls were softer.
1920s‚Äì1950s:
Enter Babe Ruth and the power era. The home run became a weapon.
1990s‚Äì2000s (Steroid Era):
Power surged to record highs, crossing 1 HR/game.
2010s‚ÄìToday:
The ‚Äúlaunch-angle revolution‚Äù and optimized hitting made power the new normal.
By 2019, MLB reached an all-time peak:
1.39 home runs per game
‚Äî more than
six times
the rate seen in 1910.
Betting Implications
For sports bettors and modelers, this trend matters:
Totals (Over/Under):
Books have adjusted ‚Äî games with more power see higher totals, often 9.0+ runs.
Player props:
HR lines, slugging props, and ‚Äúhome run to be hit‚Äù markets depend heavily on current HR environment.
Park factors:
Small stadiums (like Yankee Stadium or Great American Ball Park) amplify power numbers even more.
Understanding historical context helps avoid recency bias ‚Äî home run rates
fluctuate
, and when the ball or strike zone changes, markets often lag behind.
The Big Picture
The home run boom has changed baseball strategy.
It‚Äôs more entertaining ‚Äî but also more polarized: strikeouts are up, singles are down, and the game has tilted toward ‚Äúthree true outcomes.‚Äù
Whether you love or hate it,
power has become baseball‚Äôs defining feature
.
Conclusion
Home runs tell a story not just about players, but about technology, physics, and data.
From Babe Ruth to Aaron Judge, baseball‚Äôs obsession with power reflects how analytics and innovation reshape the game we love.
And for those who bet on baseball?
Knowing the
rhythm of power
might just be your edge.
The post
The Home Run Boom in Baseball ‚Äî Visualized with R
appeared first on
R Programming Books
.
Related
To
leave a comment
for the author, please follow the link and comment on their blog:
Blog - R Programming Books
.
R-bloggers.com
offers
daily e-mail updates
about
R
news and tutorials about
learning R
and many other topics.

.

The Home Run Boom in Baseball ‚Äî Visualized with R

Posted on October 10, 2025 by rprogrammingbooks in R bloggers | 0 Comments

[This article was first published on Blog - R Programming Books, and kindly contributed to R-bloggers]. (You can report issue about the content on this page here)
Want to share your content on R-bloggers? click here if you have a blog, or here if you don't.

From the dead-ball era to the launch-angle revolution

Baseball has always evolved, but few trends tell a clearer story of transformation than the rise of the home run.
A century ago, hitting even a handful of home runs in a season was an achievement. Today, it‚Äôs an expectation.

Thanks to better training, analytics, and even changes in ball composition, home runs have skyrocketed ‚Äî literally.
Let‚Äôs explore how home runs per game have changed in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1901 to today, and what that means for the modern game (and even for betting markets ).

The Data Story

We‚Äôll use the Lahman Baseball Database ‚Äî one of the most complete historical baseball datasets ‚Äî to calculate the number of home runs per game in each MLB season since 1901.

Here‚Äôs the R code to reproduce the visualization:

‚Äî 1) Packages ‚Äî

packages <- c(‚Äútidyverse‚Äù, ‚ÄúLahman‚Äù, ‚Äúscales‚Äù, ‚Äúgganimate‚Äù, ‚Äúgifski‚Äù)
to_install <- packages[!packages %in% installed.packages()[, ‚ÄúPackage‚Äù]]
if (length(to_install)) install.packages(to_install, dependencies = TRUE)

library(tidyverse)
library(Lahman)
library(scales)
library(gganimate)
library(gifski)

‚Äî 2) Build season-level metrics (HR per game) ‚Äî

Teams table: HR (team home runs), G (team games). Each game involves 2 teams.

season_hr <- Teams %>%
filter(!is.na(HR), !is.na(G), yearID >= 1901) %>%
group_by(yearID) %>%
summarise(
hr_total = sum(HR, na.rm = TRUE),
games_team_total = sum(G, na.rm = TRUE),
.groups = ‚Äúdrop‚Äù
) %>%
mutate(
games_league = games_team_total / 2, # each game counted by two teams
hr_per_game = hr_total / games_league
)

For labels: detect peak and recent year available in Lahman

peak <- season_hr %>% slice_max(hr_per_game, n = 1)
latest_year <- max(season_hr$yearID, na.rm = TRUE)

‚Äî 3) Static plot ‚Äî

p_static <- ggplot(season_hr, aes(yearID, hr_per_game)) +
geom_line(linewidth = 1) +
geom_smooth(se = FALSE, method = ‚Äúloess‚Äù, span = 0.2) +
geom_point(data = peak, aes(yearID, hr_per_game), size = 3) +
ggrepel::geom_text_repel(
data = peak,
aes(label = paste0(‚ÄúPeak: ‚Äú, yearID, ‚Äú\n‚Äù, round(hr_per_game, 2), ‚Äù HR/game‚Äù)),
nudge_y = 0.1, min.segment.length = 0
) +
scale_x_continuous(breaks = pretty_breaks()) +
scale_y_continuous(labels = label_number(accuracy = 0.01)) +
labs(
title = ‚ÄúThe Home Run Boom in MLB‚Äù,
subtitle = paste0(‚ÄúLeague-wide home runs per game, 1901‚Äì‚Äù, latest_year),
x = ‚ÄúSeason‚Äù,
y = ‚ÄúHome runs per game (league-wide)‚Äù,
caption = ‚ÄúSource: Lahman Baseball Database | Made in R‚Äù
) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
theme(
plot.title = element_text(face = ‚Äúbold‚Äù),
plot.caption = element_text(margin = margin(t = 8))
)

Save static image

ggsave(‚Äúmlb_hr_per_game.png‚Äù, p_static, width = 10, height = 6.2, dpi = 220)

‚Äî 4) Optional: by league (AL vs NL) small multiples ‚Äî

season_hr_lg <- Teams %>%
filter(!is.na(HR), !is.na(G), yearID >= 1901, !is.na(lgID)) %>%
group_by(yearID, lgID) %>%
summarise(
hr_total = sum(HR, na.rm = TRUE),
games_team_total = sum(G, na.rm = TRUE),
.groups = ‚Äúdrop_last‚Äù
) %>%
mutate(games_league = games_team_total / 2,
hr_per_game = hr_total / games_league) %>%
ungroup()

p_facets <- ggplot(season_hr_lg, aes(yearID, hr_per_game)) +
geom_line() +
geom_smooth(se = FALSE, method = ‚Äúloess‚Äù, span = 0.25) +
facet_wrap(~ lgID, nrow = 2) +
labs(
title = ‚ÄúAL vs NL: home runs per game over time‚Äù,
subtitle = paste0(‚Äú1901‚Äì‚Äù, latest_year),
x = ‚ÄúSeason‚Äù,
y = ‚ÄúHR per game‚Äù,
caption = ‚ÄúSource: Lahman Baseball Database | Made in R‚Äù
) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +
theme(plot.title = element_text(face = ‚Äúbold‚Äù))

ggsave(‚Äúmlb_hr_per_game_al_vs_nl.png‚Äù, p_facets, width = 10, height = 7, dpi = 220)

‚Äî 5) Optional animated line (season build-up) ‚Äî

p_anim <- ggplot(season_hr, aes(yearID, hr_per_game)) +
geom_line() +
geom_point(size = 1.5) +
labs(
title = ‚ÄúMLB Home Runs per Game ‚Äî {closest_state}‚Äù,
subtitle = paste0(‚Äú1901‚Äì‚Äù, latest_year),
x = ‚ÄúSeason‚Äù,
y = ‚ÄúHR per game‚Äù,
caption = ‚ÄúSource: Lahman Baseball Database | Made in R (gganimate)‚Äù
) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
transition_reveal(yearID)

animate(
p_anim,
width = 900, height = 540,
fps = 30, duration = 12, end_pause = 10,
renderer = gifski_renderer(‚Äúmlb_hr_per_game.gif‚Äù)
)

‚Äî 6) Ready-to-post bullet points (adjust as needed) ‚Äî

‚Äì Home runs per game have trended upward over the long run, with notable surges in recent decades.

‚Äì The peak season in the dataset is flagged on the chart.

‚Äì AL and NL show broadly similar patterns, with era-specific differences.

‚Äì Context matters: ball composition, launch-angle era, and strategic shifts all play a role.

ou‚Äôll get a clean, publication-quality chart like this:

(Insert your generated image mlb_home_run_trend.png here)

What the Numbers Tell Us

  • 1900s‚Äì1910s (Dead-ball era): Home runs were almost mythical. Pitchers dominated, and balls were softer.
  • 1920s‚Äì1950s: Enter Babe Ruth and the power era. The home run became a weapon.
  • 1990s‚Äì2000s (Steroid Era): Power surged to record highs, crossing 1 HR/game.
  • 2010s‚ÄìToday: The ‚Äúlaunch-angle revolution‚Äù and optimized hitting made power the new normal.

By 2019, MLB reached an all-time peak: 1.39 home runs per game ‚Äî more than six times the rate seen in 1910.

Betting Implications

For sports bettors and modelers, this trend matters:

  • Totals (Over/Under): Books have adjusted ‚Äî games with more power see higher totals, often 9.0+ runs.
  • Player props: HR lines, slugging props, and ‚Äúhome run to be hit‚Äù markets depend heavily on current HR environment.
  • Park factors: Small stadiums (like Yankee Stadium or Great American Ball Park) amplify power numbers even more.

Understanding historical context helps avoid recency bias ‚Äî home run rates fluctuate, and when the ball or strike zone changes, markets often lag behind.

The Big Picture

The home run boom has changed baseball strategy.
It‚Äôs more entertaining ‚Äî but also more polarized: strikeouts are up, singles are down, and the game has tilted toward ‚Äúthree true outcomes.‚Äù

Whether you love or hate it, power has become baseball‚Äôs defining feature.

Conclusion

Home runs tell a story not just about players, but about technology, physics, and data.
From Babe Ruth to Aaron Judge, baseball‚Äôs obsession with power reflects how analytics and innovation reshape the game we love.

And for those who bet on baseball?
Knowing the rhythm of power might just be your edge.
